revelation.title: Book of Revelation Study
revelation.subtitle: A Chapter-by-Chapter, Verse-by-Verse Journey
revelation.description: Dive deep into the prophetic visions of John and discover the profound truths of Christ's final revelation to humanity.

1.title: The Revelation of Jesus Christ
1.summary: John receives the divine revelation and introduces the prophetic visions that will follow. This chapter establishes the authority, purpose, and blessed nature of the entire book.
1.introduction: The visions of this book are presented as an 'unveiling of hidden truths,' a revelation of God's sovereignty over the future, showing how He will bring an end to the apparent success of the forces of evil in this world

1.title: Prologue: The Chain of Revelation (1:1-3)
1.content: Revelation opens with a declaration of origin and purpose. Here, 'revelation' (ἀποκάλυψις, apokalypsis) literally means 'to remove the veil,' to highlight what was hidden and is now made explicit. This 'Revelation' is, therefore, more than a prophecy about the end; it is a revelation of Jesus himself, where He explains in detail the plan of redemption.
keyInsights: The path of revelation is fourfold: God → Jesus → angel → John → churches
The verb 'show' (σημαίνω, sēmainō) indicates figurative and symbolic language
'Servants' (δοῦλος, doulos) broadens the scope: the entire community of faith
The 'things which must shortly take place' echo Daniel 2:28-30

2.title: Eyewitness: Word and Testimony (1:2)
2.content: John presents himself as one who 'bore witness to the word of God, and to the testimony of Jesus Christ, to all things that he saw.' The term 'testimony' (μαρτυρία, martyria) refers to the prophetic mission and commitment to revealed truth, even in the face of persecution.
keyInsights: The 'word of God' echoes Genesis 1 and John 1
The testimony of Jesus is the essence of the prophetic spirit (cf. 19:10)
John assumes the posture of a faithful messenger like the ancient prophets

3.title: Beatitude of the Reader (1:3)
3.content: Revelation begins with the first of seven beatitudes, highlighting the value of reading, hearing, and practicing the message. It is not enough to read superficially; it is necessary to listen carefully and obey, allowing the text to shape one's life.
keyInsights: 'Keep' is a recurring verb, indicating commitment to God's will
The blessing is for those who persevere, for 'the time is near'
The point is not speculation, but readiness and faithfulness

4.title: Trinitarian Greeting and Doxology (1:4-6)
4.content: The immediate recipient is 'the seven churches which are in Asia,' representing the totality of God's people of all times. The threefold greeting highlights the sovereign and saving work of the Trinity: the Father, the Spirit, and the Son act in perfect unity to redeem and sustain the people.
keyInsights: Christ is presented in three titles: Faithful Witness, Firstborn from the dead, Ruler of kings
He 'loved us and washed us from our sins in His own blood'
He makes His people 'kings and priests' (Ex 19:6), called to service and witness

5.title: Eschatological Announcement (1:7-8)
5.content: 'Behold, He is coming with clouds, and every eye will see Him...' The return of Christ will be universal, visible, and transformative, reversing all injustice and rejection. The phrase 'I am the Alpha and the Omega...' emphasizes God's absolute sovereignty over all history.
keyInsights: Even 'those who pierced Him' will experience revelation and mourning
God is the beginning and the end, the Lord of time and destiny
Able to fulfill all His promises

6.title: Christ in the Midst of the Golden Lampstands (1:9-20)
6.content: John identifies with his readers as 'brother and companion in the tribulation and kingdom and patience.' The central vision presents Christ walking 'in the midst of the seven golden lampstands' (the churches), as the 'Son of Man,' clothed as High Priest and King.

symbolism.head_hair: Head and hair white: image of the 'Ancient of Days' (Dan 7:9)
symbolism.eyes: Eyes like a flame of fire: penetration and judgment (Dan 10:6)
symbolism.feet: Feet like fine brass: firmness, purity and victory over evil
symbolism.voice: Voice as the sound of many waters: majesty and divine power (Ezek 1:24)
symbolism.stars: Seven stars in His right hand: authority over the angels of the churches
symbolism.sword: Sharp two-edged sword: the divine Word, which judges and liberates
symbolism.countenance: Countenance like the sun: divine glory, messianic victory

keyInsights: Christ declares He has 'the keys of Hades and of Death'
Christ reigns even in the midst of His church's suffering

1.text: The Revelation of Jesus Christ, which God gave Him to show His servants—things which must shortly take place. And He sent and signified it by His angel to His servant John,
1.commentary: Revelation opens with a declaration of origin and purpose. Here, 'revelation' (ἀποκάλυψις, apokalypsis) literally means 'to remove the veil,' to highlight what was hidden and is now made explicit. The term, which appears 18 times in the New Testament, always indicates a divine act of revelation.
keyPoints: Divine origin - revelation of Jesus Christ which God gave Him
Purpose - to show His servants things which must shortly take place
Method - through angel sent to John
The term 'signified' (σημαίνω) indicates use of signs and symbols
1.application: This 'Revelation' is more than a prophecy about the end; it is a revelation of Jesus himself, where He explains in detail the plan of redemption. Therefore, many consider Revelation as the 'Fifth Gospel,' for in it all of God's promises converge and are fulfilled.
1.greekNotes: ἀποκάλυψις (apokalypsis) - unveiling, revelation; σημαίνω (sēmainō) - to make known by signs

2.text: who bore witness to the word of God, and to the testimony of Jesus Christ, to all things that he saw.
2.commentary: John presents himself as one who 'bore witness to the word of God, and to the testimony of Jesus Christ, to all things that he saw.' The term 'testimony' (μαρτυρία, martyria) refers to the prophetic mission and commitment to revealed truth, even in the face of persecution.
keyPoints: John as faithful and complete witness
Testimony includes both word of God and testimony of Jesus
Nothing is omitted from the revelation - 'all things that he saw'
The 'testimony of Jesus' is identified as the essence of the prophetic spirit (cf. 19:10)
2.application: The expression 'word of God' echoes Genesis 1 ('Let there be light') and John 1 ('In the beginning was the Word'), showing that revelation is creative and recreative. The central content is Christ, who acts as mediator and also as the theme of revelation.
2.greekNotes: μαρτυρία (martyria) - testimony, witness; ἐμαρτύρησεν (emarturesen) - testified, bore witness

3.text: Blessed is he who reads and those who hear the words of this prophecy, and keep those things which are written in it; for the time is near.
3.commentary: Revelation begins with the first of seven beatitudes, highlighting the value of reading, hearing, and practicing the message. It is not enough to read superficially; it is necessary to listen carefully and obey, allowing the text to shape one's life.
keyPoints: First of seven beatitudes in Revelation
Three blessed actions: read, hear, and keep
Urgency emphasized - 'for the time is near'
3.application: 'Keep' is a recurring verb throughout the book, indicating commitment to God's will even amid pressures. The blessing is for those who persevere, for 'the time is near': the point is not speculation, but readiness and faithfulness.
3.greekNotes: μακάριος (makarios) - blessed, happy; τηρεῖν (terein) - to keep, observe, obey

2.title: Letters to Four Churches
2.summary: Messages to Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, and Thyatira

1.text: To the angel of the church in Ephesus write: These are the words of him who holds the seven stars in his right hand and walks among the seven golden lampstands.
1.commentary: The first letter is addressed to the church in Ephesus, one of the major cities of Asia Minor. Christ presents himself as the one who holds the stars (the angels/pastors of the churches) and walks among the lampstands (the churches).
1.application: Christ is actively present in His church today, watching and caring for each congregation. Pastors are in His hands, and He personally oversees every local church.
